Welcome to our third session,
"Mobilizing for a National Response," featuring professor
Juliette Kayyem of the Harvard

Kennedy School. Our moderator is HBS and
HKS Professor Dutch Leonard.

Please note that a
recording of this session will be made available to
a broader public audience. If during Q&A you're called
on to pose a question,

your name and voice will
be part of that recording. If you have a tech problem,
the best thing to do

is log out and then log back in. We are turning on the chat
function for this session

so you can have
substantive conversations among yourselves and with us. Via chat, we may occasionally
pull in somebody from the chat

stream to pose a question. Over to you, Dutch. Thank you so much,
Andy, and good morning

and welcome to all of you. I'm using this background. I'm actually not standing
in a Harvard Business School classroom, but I
thought you all might

like to be welcome back
to the physical space that we all know and love. So good morning to all of you.

As Andy said, I'm Dutch Leonard,
and it's a huge pleasure to be with you all. I wish we were in
better circumstances

and to have a chance
to work with one of my very favorite colleagues
from the Harvard Kennedy School, Juliette Kayyem.

Juliette and I worked together
a lot in the Kennedy School's crisis management
programs, and we never

thought we were going to
be living through an event like this, as we are, but it's
nice to at least have a chance

to think about it and talk
about it with all of you. I also want to congratulate
the organizers today. We've got two previous
discussions this morning,

which were just
terrific and which perfectly set up what we're
going to be talking about here. What we want to focus
on is the question

of response, national
response, individual response, firm response. And to say just a few words
about that before we start,

let me observe that the
challenge of response is much broader
than just thinking

about COVID-19 as a medical
event, and that I thought was really wonderful in
the previous session,

where Dr. Ashish Jha laid
out the fact that, obviously, there's a whole set of
medical issues here,

but the crisis goes
far beyond that. And that's what we want to
talk about in this session. It's the broader aspects
of response, the broader

aspects of wrapping our arms
around the whole enterprise. Now, as Juliette and
I teach in our courses

on crisis management,
any major emergency event is a volcano of
issues, questions,

decisions that have to be made
task and have to be undertaken. In most events, we're
familiar with those tasks.

So in a hurricane,
you know pretty much what those things are going
to be, what the questions are, what the issues are going
to be, but in a novel

event like COVID-19, you
have a whole set of questions that you never saw before, and
so the events like this, what

we call true crisis
events, confront us with a very daunting
question and confront leaders with a daunting question,
which is, what do we do

when no one knows what to do? Now there's only one
possible answer to that.

Someone has to figure it out. Someone has to wrap their arms
around the event as a whole, trying to understand
the event, and then

engage in rapid, agile,
iterative problem solving over and over and over again.

Now, they have to do that under
stress and embedded in fear, and most individuals
are not intrinsically good at that and/or
ready to do that,

and most organizations are not
intrinsically ready to do that. So the challenge is that when
we have that kind of level

of stress and not
everyone's good at it, where do we find the
someones who are good at it?

One of those someones,
one of those people who has regularly had to
help us try to figure out

what to do when no
one knew what to do is Juliette Kayyem,
our guest today. Now you've seen her
on CNN, actually,

much as she appears
now in that same room in her house in Cambridge. You've read about
her in The Atlantic.

You read her commentary in The
Atlantic and in other places. Among may other
major involvements that she's had in events that
you would remember, Juliette

Security during the H1N1 event,

to help us figure out what to do

in that and to focus

your chat on the issues that
we're talking about here, but just to give
commentary or reactions,

you're welcome to
use chat to do that. Juliette, it's
great that you're-- Thank you. --with us today.

spill just for a moment. OK. I've heard you say on a
number of occasions that

was the spill itself,
and then there was the event and the
crisis beyond that. Say a little bit more about
what you mean by that.

What's the distinction,

everyone at the business school

for having me and Dutch for us
doing another event together, which is--

I guess that's the silver
lining of everything going on, and thank you all for tuning
in to what Dutch and I are

going to talk about today. So my background, of

So I think about how governance
structures within our homeland really impact both
our capabilities

and responsibilities around
crisis response and disaster management.

I've also been fortunate
to work in state government as Deval Patrick's homeland
security advisor and then federal government.

So this federalism

is in charge and who

gets to do what between mayors,
governors, and presidents. And that played out really

I bet you if I polled all of
you watching, you would say,
oh the BP oil spill? Why would she promote that? That was horrible.

So that's probably true in
the sense of a narrative, but it's not true in the
sense of the response.

So what Dutch was picking up
on is that every crisis has

its response, right,
which is the saving of lives and minimizing
of property damage that-- minimizing of
environmental damage,

different than the response.

So if you ask me, was the BP
oil spill response a success? I would say, given
everything going on,

because I live in the world
where bad things have already happened, yes, an
ocean was saved, right?

Less oil hit shore. The industries were back up and
running within three months, right? You don't know that, because
it was madness, you know?

The narrative was madness. And what that
narrative is, we have to be conscious of when
we're fighting a crisis,

the middle of a crisis. For the BP oil
spill, that narrative is probably one that
many of you forget.

It was a narrative about the
future of the oil industry. This was before LNG came on--

natural gas came on
board and the future of offshore drilling. It was about the legacy

These were the same
five states that had been impacted by Katrina

It was about that
the future of--

I guess it was about
politics, right? So there were five
Republican governors, one Democratic president.

Three of those
governors would run against the president in his
reelect, and all of those formed this cacophony madness,
but the operations still

happened. And they were successful
because, in crisis management, you don't judge--

you don't judge things by
whether something bad has happened. You're already there, right? You're already in
response, right?

And you can blame, and
you can have commissions. You can figure out
what went wrong. Your measure of success
is, did less oil hit

shore than it
otherwise would have because of the government's
efforts, right? And so that's how I
think about today.

What's my number, right? Is 100,000 good? Well, if I entered this
thinking 1.2 million,

yes, that's a good response. It's not good in
any existential way,

but that's how we have to think
about how these narratives interact with a response.

So, Juliette, I think
it's really interesting place for us to start
into the COVID-19 event. Part of what you're
saying is that it's

hard to know what
the baseline is or what the metrics or
what you're measuring against if we've never been
through an event like this

sort of operationally

in terms of where are we
in the response and then where are we going, right,
which we can talk about as well.

And so what I do when
I teach and advise-- Dutch and I are involved
with the mayor's program

as well as governors and
CEOs and others I advise is-- I try to-- my yoga is
I put method to chaos,

and I thought that this would
be helpful for all of you, and I'll leave it

this, I teach this stuff,

and my brain was just on fire. I could not figure out
sort of where were we,

and it was important
for me to be able to ground people I advise
and the students I teach

in sort of where are
we so that the bad news is coronavirus is new. The good news is is that
crisis management is not.

And so what I'm trying
to do for all of you is try to position us
in sort of where we are.

So every crisis has five stages. So you have protection
and prevention, which is what we call left of boom.

which would have-- we would have benefited from a
strong identification system, transparency from China,
all of those things.

And that, with coronavirus, is
before December 2019, right?

All of that would
have been we have a system that's prepared
for a potential pandemic.

Then you have the prevention
stage, which, for us, this is a US-based, is
between December 2019

and February 2020, which has now
been described, as most of you have probably read, as
the squander time, right?

In other words, we are trying
to prevent the US from suffering a 50-state crisis, right, a
50-state pandemic, and here's

all the things that we might
have done to prevent it, right? We might have had better testing
kits, better notification

systems, and we
would have prepared the public and employees.

That didn't happen. And then we're at
the boom stage, which is actually not a stage. It's just the moment
of crisis, and as Dutch

was saying earlier, you know,
when you have a hurricane or earthquake, it happens. It's done, and it's
easy to mobilize.

Your response is super
easy because there's, like, damage and bodies-- and all-- it's like you don't
question when you activate.

The problem with a slow-roll
crisis like a pandemic is, of course, there is no
single moment of clarity,

homeland was the San Francisco mayor, who's going to emerge
as the hero, or heroine in all

of this, London Breed,

And she's-- they're on lockdown
two weeks before most other

places, and so you have
this activation challenge, and that meant you had a
disjointed response a White

House in denial that does
not take ownership of sort of a national strategy, and
then that's when you see

the emergence of the
mayors and governors. I'll just quickly go to response
because I think it's helpful. This is where we are, and look
at where we are on response.

We're at the beginning
of response, people. It's hard to accept,
but most places have not

flattened the curve, as we've
now come to understand it,

but we are mobilizing on
a personal, public sector, and institutional level. The personal, of

to plan for long-term
social distancing. It's the washing of the
hands, the masks, everything,

shaming involved that you--

which has been
probably the one that's been the most challenging. Right now, the
surging of resources is not happening as we know it.

You'll have social
distancing restrictions that are different
by jurisdiction, and then, of course, the
economic protections that we

need to put in place because
so many people are damaged.

And I view that as part of
the operational response.

I don't view the economy
as separate from society. It is part of it.

So it's part of our
operational response, and then, finally, the
institutional, and this is where it gets interesting.

We're at an institution now,
and they made a decision. I'm sure it was jarring
for many of you. You know that we're out of here.

We're out of Harvard. We got to get to essential
and non-essential functions and think about
continuity of operations.

We are at the beginning
of this, right, even countries that have
overcome the curve, like Italy,

under a lockdown.

This talk of opening
up is important because you need an eyes on the
prize, but it's about metrics.

It's not about a date. So I have here March 2020
until a question mark,

and governors are pushing
that envelope, people. I mean, if you
heard Charlie Baker, he refuses to answer it
here in Massachusetts.

I think we're going to
get into adaptive recovery later so for me to talk about. But then basically the next two
are recovery and resiliency.

So this is just a way for
you all to think about, well, where am I because you're
part of this, right, and what are the challenges?

And I guess I'll just
end with this chart. We're going to come back
to adaptive recovery is a crisis hits a nation.

I often say a crisis
hits a nation as it is, not as we would like it to be.

It's worth remembering the
challenges our nation has from health care and
workers' rights and the gig

economy and racism

income inequality that was wrong

care, plays out again here, and so we're all grappling

spread, so this-- you know, that we only

Security class,

security is the easy part. It's the homeland

that federalism

is both descriptive

to tell you, is that all
50 states are operationally

local execution, so think

state coordination,

given Governor Baker thinking-- and/or Governor Cuomo

most disasters

It's just a sort of pay-and-play

what to do in

that basically they

President Trump is
as not invoked yet, but you're seeing a lot more

regional coordination

it's really helpful,

thing so different pieces

take charge on the areas where

So that's going to be border
controls in that period of time that I told you between

and I just want
to be clear here, I've got very strong feelings

Test preparation kits

Communication-- I think
